entry.title: Sorting maps by multiple keys in Clojure
entry.content:
As keywords are also Clojure functions, it is very simple to sort maps by a specific key:

``` clj Sorting map by single key mark:6-8 (sort-by :score [

         {:name "Fred" :age 10 :score 9 :tuition true}
         {:name "Jim"  :age 15 :score 7 :tuition true}
         {:name "Jane" :age 9 :score 8  :tuition false}])

({:name “Jim”, :age 15, :score 7} {:name “Jane”, :age 9, :score 8} {:name “Fred”, :age 10, :score 9}) ```

However, what if we want to sort a map by multiple keys, such as :age and then :score? We can’t just add the second keyword to sort-by.

What we need is a new function that can take many comparator functions and apply them each in turn. Fortunately for us, a function already exists, namely ‘juxt.

Rewriting the function with juxt we now get:

``` clj Sorting map by multiple keys mark:6-9 (sort-by (juxt :score :age) [

         {:name "Fred" :age 10 :score 9 :tuition true}
         {:name "Jim"  :age 15 :score 7 :tuition true}
         {:name "Jane" :age 9 :score 8  :tuition false}])

({:name “Jim”, :age 15, :score 7, :tuition true} {:name “Jane”, :age 9, :score 8, :tuition false} {:name “Fred”, :age 10, :score 9, :tuition true}) ```

Great! But now what if we want to also rank by those students who take extra tuition? You’d expect the following to work, but it orders the boolean false-true rather than true-false:

``` clj Sorting map by multiple keys and boolean (sort-by (juxt :tuition :score :age) [

         {:name "Fred" :age 10 :score 9 :tuition true}
         {:name "Jim"  :age 15 :score 7 :tuition true}
         {:name "Jane" :age 9 :score 8  :tuition false}])

```
